author: @erikapapi
text: I like this format of political discourse‚Äî long form, multiple perspectives, attempts at accountability in real time,and the imperceptible forms of communication amongst people with shared identities. I really like this contribution, Olay & friends.

replies.author: @squillenial
replies.text: I agree with all this! Plus, I love the moments of Malcolm saying "Educate me on that", both because it's refreshing to have someone just stop the conversation to request that, and because it's great to see the whole panel actually stop in order to do so, rather than mock in a "how do you not know that" kind of way. It's all part of making it a real discussion, but something that stood out to me in a good way.

author: @jojodelacroix
text: I might be a white girl, but I still remember my first experience with racist cops from when I was real young. My mom and I were driving along, minding our business. I had the seat leaned back a little bit and our car had slightly tented windows. The cop pulled us over and when he realized it was a white lady and her young daughter they were like "Oh. I thought you were some black thugs" or something to that effect and then let us go. We didn't do anything wrong except driving under the suspicion of possibly being black. No wonder cops hate tented windows. It's harder to accurately racially profile that way.

replies.author: @kingcarcas1349
replies.text: Yet most cops have tinted windows on their cars

author: @PerseusManchild
text:
Did you know that police in the USA only solve 2% of all crimes?

Most of it comes from a scholarly analysis of crime rates by Shima Baughman, professor of Criminal Law at the University of Utah. ‚ÄúCrime and the Mythology of Police,‚Äù was published in the Washington University Law Review in 2020. Her work has been cited as the source for the claim by publications as diverse as The Conversation, Snopes and Pew Research Center.

‚ÄúIn reality, about 11% of all serious crimes result in an arrest, and about 2% end in a conviction," ¬†Baughman wrote in Snopes, "the number of people police hold accountable for crimes ‚Äî what I call the 'criminal accountability' rate ‚Äî is very low,‚Äù¬†

I say we need to at least overhaul the police. ¬†If any other service provider had a 2% success rate they would've been cancelled.

author: @kamaur01
text: I love the discussion. The missing part of the discussion Olay should bring up is that simple marketing doesn't work. You are marketing against something established, repackaged, and resold for centuries. Then, they will hire researchers, pay them off to get an answer they like, and market that as scientific data. "Liberals" are great with ideas but don't have the establishment to look at the long game. The other side has the long game already working for them, so they don't need to do much to coop or disrupt a "Liberal's" idea.

author: @kmfdm5
text: As a black Marxist Leninist, I am of notion that the police only have two fundamental functions. 1. To protect private property and capital 2. To maintain the the capitalist/imperialist/white supremacist hierarchy. The first purpose the police served within the construction of America and liberalism was to maintain the slave the state by capturing run away slaves. That essential function hasn‚Äôt changed all that much, it just goes by different names be it under tough on crime/broken window policies, the crime bill, or the war on drugs. The police also maintain white supremacist imperialist power structures overseas. Far right US backed dictators such as Pinochet and Batista were trained in American police departments. This is just a small sample of my impromptu thesis. The police under the current institution and existential conditions cannot be reformed or changed. That is a delusion of bourgeois liberals who actually profit off the existing hegemony and counterintuitive to what reactionaries expect out the the police institution and the police state which is to protect private property/finance capital and maintain white supremacist hegemony/hierarchy

author: @Fooacta
text:
I've found that oftentimes, you'll be forced to engage with the system even when you don't want to. 

For example: my car was stolen 6-7 months back and I figured it was 50/50 whether it would turn up a few blocks down in about a week. I still wanted to put in a claim with insurance so they could either pay out or cover repairs but they won't do shit unless you file a police report and provide a case number.

Somebody calls my car in after it gets dumped in their yard a few days later and the cops notify me, but tell me I can't claim it without them taking my prints and agreeing to testify if they pin it on somebody. I don't know if requiring any of that shit was legal or enforcable but you best believe I signed that paper and gave my prints so I could get my shit and go.

replies.author: @Fooacta
replies.text: I just got to bro giving the same example lol

author: @gabrielmccray3457
text: This was a great conversation. I'm not black but a biracial old head. I've never had a cop save the day for me. grew up in a time and place where cops  were not the go to solution. Cops were the last ditch effort. And I think this is the correct mentality.

replies.author: @TreeHairedGingerAle
replies.text:
For real!

Grew up watching my mom try again and again to call these cops to stop my dad from beating and SAing us. They never did anything except shrug with a "sorry ma'am, but...", until the day that I was big enough to fight back, in which case they considered ME the problem... 

And no wonder! I hear now, years later, that a group of cops in the same area were straight up hiding and protecting a child prostitution ring right over _near_ us, in exchange for services and a cut of the profits.

Cops are nothing but another gang, they are NOT the solution. And I've had chats with other abuse survivors -- who have similar or worse stories -- who will tell people the exact same thing: cops NEVER actually helped them! If anything, cops just protected the abusers.

author: @Beergardening
text: As a poor white kid in an ex industrial town in the Midwest I was the only white person when I went to college that was afraid of the cops. I assumed everyone had the same fear and was shocked when people suggested calling the cops over a break in. I just always moved on knowing cops would just harass me and I'd get in trouble over my car being broken into.

author: @NotSoCivilEngineer
text:
37:50 a very small but I think somewhat important bit of information:

When Republicans challenged the Affordable Care Act, SCOTUS made rulings on two key aspects of the law: the individual mandate and the Medicaid expansion. A majority ruled that the individual mandate was constitutional, but a majority ruled that the Medicaid expansion was unconstitutional.

The result of the latter was that states had to opt into a Medicaid expansion to get federal funds for it. Predictably, multiple Republican-controlled states refused to do the Medicaid expansion.

I thought this was important to bring up since I know the discussion has come up before that a lot of times, we don‚Äôt understand how our state and local governments impede or embrace federal policies that may make measurable differences (both positive and negative) in people‚Äôs lives. A more recent example of this is how multiple Republican-controlled states have refused to accept recent federal funds to aid with combatting child hunger.

And because it‚Äôs probably necessary to say this, no, I‚Äôm not shilling for Democrats. I‚Äôd be a fool to do that in Olay‚Äôs comments section, especially with the list of legitimate criticisms that can be leveled against them.

author: @noneofya9081
text: One of the problems with law enforcement is that it often recruits individuals with prior military experience who are already somewhat trained, and in some cases, have combat experience. This, coupled with training that portrays the public as the enemy, contributes to current issues.

replies.author: @llw106
replies.text: I can see that possibly being true... But I can also see a case where a military person is more disciplined, possibly more respectful and less likely to just resort to pulling out a gun out of fear than an ordinary citizen solely trained by the police. Maybe it's an individual by individual case

replies.author: @noneofya9081
replies.text: I must disagree. My observations during my time in law enforcement have demonstrated that those are the last people who should be dealing with the public. The ability to dehumanize an enemy combatant and justify savagery against them also comes with the discipline and whatnot. However, there is no UCMJ for them to worry about, only a citizenry that mostly reveres them and overlooks their bad behavior.

replies.author: @llw106
replies.text: @noneofya9081¬† I'm not going to argue with that. You made an intriguing point which made me think about who makes the best officers. I have been watching a lot of videos on police engaging the public and honestly, all of it needs an overhaul. Decent educated people who can critically think should be cops. The fact that a city needs to hire more police and increase the budget means that they are failing the people and not making a better community for all. Nobody looks at it like that

replies.author: @noneofya9081
replies.text: The NYPD requires a minimum of 60 college credits for recruitment. It's not a lack of education that's the problem. The core issue lies with the individual in the uniform and their perception of those over whom they hold power. Even a well-educated officer with military experience can still resort to violence and lethal force.

replies.author: @john2g1
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã@noneofya9081 people are people. You can never make generalizations like that. 

I strongly believe that your observation bias is a result of the people in charge of hiring in that department wanting a specific type of soldier to turn into a cop. 

On the opposite end of the spectrum the soldiers I served with lean towards either constitutionalist or if it's not a capital crime it's not worth the paperwork. 

To be clear the constitutionalists are die-hards for freedom of speech, right to film (the police), right to bear arms, right to privacy, property and person. Basically the opposite of what a questionable department would want in a future hire. 

To piggyback off of Olay around 29:29 the militaristic ex-military cops you witnessed are functioning exactly as they were hired to act.

replies.author: @noneofya9081
replies.text: It seems we are both operating based on observational bias. However, I have had the opportunity to observe former soldiers who are constitutionalists in action. Their beliefs falter when dealing with populations they view as 'others.' To be clear, the soldiers you refer to are the same as the officers I am discussing.

replies.author: @john2g1
replies.text:
@noneofya9081  Yes, we are both suffering from observational biases. I thought that was clear when I explained it. I'm not trying to insult you, but I was reinforcing my point: people are people they come in good and bad flavors. 

The ex-military cops you observed are the way that they are because they were hired for that purpose. The military veterans I observed were the way that they were because the ones that are like the people you described are almost always filtered out. 

What I didn't tell you was I served in the Special Operations community. Filtering out extremists and people with racial biases is a big part of the selection and qualification process. It's taken a step further when the soldiers are assigned to a unit. Leadership are required to "retrain" or remove any racially biased people from operations. They end up on the administrative support teams or kicked out of SpecOps all together.

^^That's my point... It's not that there's a problem with ex-military cops. There is a problem with police leadership specifically seeking out "door kickers" with a certain attitude.

author: @ltandrepants

author: @KeyanGootkin
text:
what a great convo. I grew up the poorest jew on the outside of a white christian suburb, when I moved to a bigger city with more black people I saw right away the way that poverty is used in conjunction with racism in policing. I was trespassing and being a hooligan and doing weird shit in that white town, because I didn‚Äôt want to be home I didn‚Äôt have things to do, and I was fine. I went to a rich black friends place and we did that sort of stuff and  we got some weird looks but it was fine. but the moment we went to the wrong neighborhood I could feel the eyes on us, i saw the patrol cars and i felt a piece of that fear and I knew I had to behave or something awful could happen because of my friends skin color. 

our communities are set up to hide all of that, to naturalize the bullshit everyone puts up with and hide the hypocrisies. the fact that I got to see those different sides is a aberration. unless you are able to be immersed in both sides, it‚Äôs really hard to convey how weaponized classism is against poc and how weaponized racism is against all poor people. both the poor as dirt white racist hick, and the classist rich black pick-me, are being tricked into putting their boot on their own neck. those separations need to come down in order for it to click for a lot of people. racism and classism are part of the same system and both reinforce each other so both need to be tackled for any real liberation to happen, otherwise you end up reinventing the same bullshit

text: The thing about thinking  "you shouldn't have to go through this" is that's another set of problems. It leaves you feeling bitter, lost, abandoned.

What do you suppose? We believe we deserve where we‚Äôre at, even if our needs aren‚Äôt even close to being taken care of?
If you feel bitter, it‚Äôs because it hurts. Use that pain for your purpose. It‚Äôs all in our thinking patterns. Like with nihilism, you can chose to passively or actively participate.

The relationship of cops to the 2nd most segregated city in the country along with a Black, mainline democratic mayor is very interesting at the least. As a Chicana who moved to Milwaukee from Texas, I loved the deep dive on the evil snake Greg Abbott, and I have been fascinated by the fact that I have seen and experienced more racism in Milwaukee, Wisconsin than I ever did in rural Texas.

author: @theajayieffect
text:
Tucking in to watch this video now, I can't wait!!! I think the issue is a messaging one. I grew up in Brownsville here in NY during the 90s. It was wild. There wasn't a clear connection to WHY things were the was the were and WHAT the police actually did.  There were very little resources, period. 

Brownsville is still under resourced. 

We need to amplify the message of what policing is about and the history of policing. As well we need to SHOUT about what the alternatives are. 

When we say remove the police, some within these communities become terrified that another "resource" is being removed. That's a lie.

I would have a car or someone to drive me around.  They only see a stereotype.  It was a waste of time and I had to wait to catch the next bus because they made me miss the first bus!

author: @adrians-ro8kk
text: Black people are not immune to 'copaganda' but also black people are not immune to fearing crime. There is a real gang problem in NYC. When you live in a neighborhood where there's Woo, Choo's, Gs9, gdk, going back and forth, fighting, shooting at each other and you have to walk through police tape to get to work, or to take your kids to school. You will eventually become weary and want cops to get involved. This is real every day life for poor black people who don't want to get caught in the crossfire of gang violence. As bad as cops are. They want to protect their family.

replies.author: @TreeHairedGingerAle
replies.text:
But the studies and data clearly show that cops don't help communities, _they harm them._

We really need to get through to people that public safety is gained through the improvement of the material conditions and services in your community. Not whether or not you have enough racist-ass storm troopers walking around underfoot, fingers on triggers and eyeing your uncle and grandma funny.

author: @josephmorgan4834
text: I have a little pushback against the brother in the suit. At one point, ~1:22:51, he equates the ownership of a mom and pop store to capitalism. This is petit bourgeois ownership at best. A true capitalist owns the means of productions (land, factories, etc.)

replies.author: @comebackkid44723
replies.text: @josephmorgan4834 petit bourgeois ownership is part of the class system though, it‚Äôs part of capitalism. They are a capitalist, albeit a much smaller fish than a member of the bourgeoisie.

replies.author: @josephmorgan4834
replies.text: @comebackkid44723 A capitalist owns the means of production. We are all a part of the class system. Nonetheless, if one's allegiances do not align with the working class, said person is an enemy of the people.

replies.author: @comebackkid44723
replies.text: @josephmorgan4834 and the petite bourgeoisie, smaller capitalists, own smaller things like shops or little family farms. They‚Äôre a mixture of capitalist class in that their wealth comes from owning property but in many cases they also have to work alongside their employees.

replies.author: @josephmorgan4834
replies.text: @comebackkid44723 I like to take a more simplistic view. In the words of Boots Riley, ‚Äúeither you‚Äôre a boss or you‚Äôre a worker.‚Äù ‚ÄúTrue capitalists‚Äù exploit the wealth of others (on a grand scale.) Still, I get you.

replies.text: It's very simple for me. When they say "If you see something, say something", I ask them does that apply to cops too?

author: @jeffreywenger281
text: For what its worth, the police probably won't find my stolen car either.  But I'll report it to the police so I can get the insurance claim, and I would hope you would too.  As for the police, I think I huge part of the problem is that American police receive very little training.  Anyone who is given a gun and told to be in control of the situation without good training is gonna kill someone.  It takes a lot of training to have the confidence to take control of a situation without hurting anyone.  And of course, its not the rich who are suffering the consequences of poor police training, so they don't feel like paying for it.  So I'd like to suggest the possibility that it might be less about racism and more about the wealthy not wanting to pay taxes because they aren't seeing the consequences of poor training.  The police for their part, would enjoy getting the opportunity to be better trained.

replies.author: @comebackkid44723
replies.text:
Police get lots of training, millions have been invested in the types of reforms liberals advocate-cameras, training, community policing programs etc-San Diego already had all of the ‚ÄúEight Can‚Äôt Wait‚Äù reforms proposed. Still had lots of brutality, violence, corruption etc
The problem is the whole system of property and policing entirely.

author: @pen4hire27
text: The problem with US policing is its history. In 1822, the British Parliament passed the Irish Constabulary Act which was designed to police hostile Ireland. Through the London Metropolitan Police Act seven years later, Britain established a local police force that was intentionally different from the military and whose mission was focused on prevention of crime rather than repression of disorder. These models became major influences on the development of policing in the United States in the 1840s. The Royal Irish Constabulary model is used to police non-whites and their neighbourhoods while Met (community) policing is used for whites and white areas.

replies.author: @comebackkid44723
replies.text: Problem with policing is what type of people this job APPEALS to. What kind of sick bastard wants that level of unassailable authority without any type of accountability over other people? Even someone who goes into it with supposedly good intentions, the culture surrounding it and molding it and the nature of power itself will corrupt them or isolate them. And those ‚Äúgood cops‚Äù either stay silent or ‚Äúcatching friendly fire‚Äù if they try and make noise.
